content.question: For time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the velocity of a particle moving in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane is given by the vector <math alttext="open angled bracket, t to the fifth power, comma, open parenthesis, 1 plus the square root of t, close parenthesis, squared, close angled bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⟩</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the position of the particle is <math alttext="4 comma 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the distance between the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
